Award.AwardTitle: SEES Fellows: A bio-economic study of an introduced biological control agent: ecological, evolutionary, and economic factors in sustainable agricultural systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
This interdisciplinary project will use advanced genomic sequencing techniques to investigate how biological control agents are established, undergo genetic variation, and adapt to novel environments. The genetic evaluation will use a globally distributed species of ladybeetle, Coccinella septempunctata, to study the relationship between human introduction efforts and demographic processes that affect the establishment and spread of this predator in the United States. The study will also include an ex-post benefit-cost analysis to assess the economic value of using C. septempunctata as a biological control agent.

Biological control, the introduction of natural enemies to control pests and weeds in agricultural systems, can promote sustainable agriculture and environment, and enhance biodiversity, food safety, and human health, by reducing the need for pesticides. Despite a long history, classical biological control has not developed as a predictive science, frequently resulting in unexpected ecological and economic costs. To improve the sustainable use of biological control agents, decision makers need better tools to understand biological control programs as multidisciplinary efforts that require integrated knowledge of ecology, evolutionary biology, and economics. This project will study a widely distributed ladybeetle as a model control agent with the intent of improving current methods and procedures for the introduction of beneficial insects for biological control applications.

The principal investigator on this project will also be an active participant in an international biological control working group, and will work with teachers and students on the design of sustainability science courses at a local middle school.

This project is supported under the NSF Science, Engineering and Education for Sustainability Fellows (SEES Fellows) program, with the goal of helping to enable discoveries needed to inform actions that lead to environmental, energy and societal sustainability while creating the necessary workforce to address these challenges. With SEES Fellows support, this project will enable a promising early career researcher to establish themselves in an independent research career related to sustainability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
To improve the sustainable use of biological control agents, the PI conducted a bio-economic study of a classical biological control program in sustainable agricultural systems. She used seven-spotted ladybird beetles, Coccinella septempunctata, as a model species in biological control. There were four major introduction periods in the USA using 11 foreign sources, and the total number of the introduced individuals was about 1.4 million. Using the historical release records and sequence data from mtDNA, she found that patterns of genetic diversity in North America were the result of both historical human releases and natural range expansion from multiple established populations. Additional genetic markers were selected and more DNA sequence data were generated using next-generation sequencing to conduct population genetic analyses in C. septempunctata, and the analysis of these data is ongoing. From the economic study of biological controls, she found that biological control included important roles in agro-economics and provided ecosystem services; therefore, the economic value of the biological control would be increased as organic food market grows in future.

Through this fellowship, she has been studying Molecular Ecology and Evolution, and has been trained to generate data using nest-generation sequencing, and learned bioinformatics for the data sorting and analyses. She also learned to conduct economic analyses. Therefore, this fellowship funding provided her, an early-career female researcher, an opportunity to continue her research programs. She expanded her research networks and developed new research skills and knowledge in science as a post-doctoral researcher. She was involved in many different conference attendances and oral and poster presentations. She organized national and international symposia in the professional scientific conferences. She also conducted seminar talks in universities, and advised and trained undergraduate and graduate students during the funding period. Finally, she was actively involved in outreach programs with teachers and students at a middle school in KY and an early education center in TN. Especially, students and teachers in KY learned basic and applied science through lectures, hands-on activities in the laboratory, greenhouse, and field experiments related to sustainable agriculture.
